bibl.title: Letter from Edwin Denby to Howard A. Kelly, October 21, 1907

div1.p: Denby discusses strategy for introducing the pension bill for Kissinger.

div1.head: Letter from Edwin Denby to Howard A. Kelly, October 21, 1907
div1.opener:
not ans
House of Representatives U.S.
Washington,D.C.
Detroit, October 21, 1907.
Howard A. Kelly Esquire,
1418 Eutaw Place,
Baltimore, Md.
My dear Mr. Kelly:
div1.p:
I have your letter of the 18th instant
in regard to the case of John R. Kissinger. You state that
Senator Whyte and Representative Mr. Mudd have promised their
assistance when required, but you do not know in what way
their kindness could be utilized and you ask my advice. The
case can be handled in several ways. If you desire it, it
can be introduced as a special bill for pension, in which
case Mr. Whyte and Mr. Mudd could be of very great value in
aiding the passage of the bill, as could also Mr. Mason,
through the Illinois delegation. Or, if it is thought ad-
visable, Senator Whyte or Mr. Mudd could introduce the bill.
Or, better still, in order to expedite matters, Senator
Whyte could introduce the bill in the Senate while Mr. Mudd
or I introduce it in the House. Of course, nothing can be
done until the convening of Congress in December.

If you wish me to put in the bill, please send me all
the data in connection with the case, Regiment, Company,
rank etc. Kissinger's service record, details concerning
House of Representatives U.S.
Washington,D.C.
H.A.K.-2-
the experiment in which he participated, and his present
condition. Affidavits should be supplied as to his physical
condition from medical men and his financial situation
from himself and several others acquainted with the facts.

I shall be happy to help secure the passage of the
bill or introduce it myself, as you may desire. In the mean-
time if you are raising more funds I shall be glad to send
you $5 or $10 for this cause. Please let me know as early
as convenient if you think it well for me to put in the
bill, as I must arrange my schedule of bills.
